channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Tessie Prevost, pioneer of Deep South school desegregation, dies at 69
item.description: Tessie Prevost was one of the young Black girls who integrated New Orleans public schools in the 1960s after federal courts forced the system to abide by the Brown vs. the Board of Education ruling.
item.content:encoded:
Tessie Prevost was one of the young Black girls who integrated New Orleans public schools in the 1960s after federal courts forced the system to abide by the Brown vs. the Board of Education ruling.

(Image credit: Ted Jackson)
item.dc:creator: Debbie Elliott

item.title: Alaska federal judge resigns after investigators say he created a hostile workplace
item.description: Judge Joshua Kindred, a Trump appointee, resigned after investigators concluded he sent crude messages to employees, engaged in sexual contact with a former law clerk and lied to colleagues about it.
item.content:encoded:
Judge Joshua Kindred, a Trump appointee, resigned after investigators concluded he sent crude messages to employees, engaged in sexual contact with a former law clerk and lied to colleagues about it.

(Image credit: U.S. Senate Committee on the Judiciary)
item.dc:creator: Carrie Johnson

item.title: Golfers travel from around the world for 3rd U.S. Adaptive Golf Open
item.description: The 3rd Annual Adaptive Golf Open is underway in Kansas as disabled golfers from 32 states and 11 countries vy for a championship. The field includes A 20 year old Utah golfer, paralyzed from a ski accident, who’s back defending the championship he won last year in the seated impairment category
item.content:encoded: The 3rd Annual Adaptive Golf Open is underway in Kansas as disabled golfers from 32 states and 11 countries vy for a championship. The field includes A 20 year old Utah golfer, paralyzed from a ski accident, who’s back defending the championship he won last year in the seated impairment category
item.dc:creator: Greg Echlin

item.title: Mate's moment at the Copa
item.description: Players at the Copa America have been seen exiting team buses with Mate gourds. Part of the point of Yerba Mate is that it's communal -- perfect to be shared with your 10 best friends after a game.
item.content:encoded: Players at the Copa America have been seen exiting team buses with Mate gourds. Part of the point of Yerba Mate is that it's communal -- perfect to be shared with your 10 best friends after a game.
item.dc:creator: Matt Ozug

item.title: Federal judge resigns after investigation uncovers abusive conduct
item.description: A federal judge in Alaska resigns after investigators conclude he created a hostile environment for law clerks and had an inappropriate relationship with one of them.
item.content:encoded: A federal judge in Alaska resigns after investigators conclude he created a hostile environment for law clerks and had an inappropriate relationship with one of them.
item.dc:creator: Carrie Johnson

item.title: Israel is divided over next steps in Gaza
item.description: Israel’s military and politicians are divided on whether to strike a ceasefire deal with Hamas. Israeli experts have presented the government with proposals for a postwar Gaza.
item.content:encoded: Israel’s military and politicians are divided on whether to strike a ceasefire deal with Hamas. Israeli experts have presented the government with proposals for a postwar Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Estrin

item.title: Fed Chair tells Congress lowering interest rates poses "two-sided risks"
item.description: Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell testified before a Senate committee today. As inflation cools, the central bank is weighing when it's safe to start cutting interest rates.
item.content:encoded: Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell testified before a Senate committee today. As inflation cools, the central bank is weighing when it's safe to start cutting interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: What can the White House do to control the narrative around Biden's ability?
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with Paul Begala, former counselor to President Clinton, about the challenge the White House has in controlling the scrutiny surrounding President Biden's ability.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with Paul Begala, former counselor to President Clinton, about the challenge the White House has in controlling the scrutiny surrounding President Biden's ability.
item.dc:creator: Elena Burnett

item.title: After a string of upsets, Wimbledon heads into quarterfinals
item.description: As quarterfinal are underway, NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with Washington Post Reporter Ava Wallace on the biggest storylines happening at Wimbledon.
item.content:encoded: As quarterfinal are underway, NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with Washington Post Reporter Ava Wallace on the biggest storylines happening at Wimbledon.
item.dc:creator: Gurjit Kaur

item.title: The physics of launching into space -- and crashing back down
item.description: Humans are traveling farther into space than ever before. We look at the physics of launch – how to send something up and how it can come crashing back down.
item.content:encoded: Humans are traveling farther into space than ever before. We look at the physics of launch – how to send something up and how it can come crashing back down.
item.dc:creator: Emily Kwong
